nodes.bodyText: This is a minor formatting inconsistency. All of the other instances have target on the same line as function.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -370,6 +405,14 @@ public IntIterable collectInt(IntFunction<? super T> intFunction)
         return this.iterable.collectInt(intFunction, target);
     }
 
+    @Override
+    public <R extends MutableIntCollection> R flatCollectInt(
+            Function<? super T, ? extends IntIterable> function,
+            R target)

nodes.bodyText: Is the cast really necessary here?

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -423,6 +473,17 @@ public BooleanIterable collectBoolean(BooleanFunction<? super T> booleanFunction
         }
     }
 
+    @Override
+    public <R extends MutableIntCollection> R flatCollectInt(
+            Function<? super T, ? extends IntIterable> function,
+            R target)

nodes.bodyText: Use a bag instead so order doesn't matter.
Use an equality test with the target bag, which will cover size and containsAll.
Use a bag for the target so order doesn't matter.
Use an equality test with the target which covers size and containsAll.
Why is this using an anonymous inner class?
Use a bag as a target so order doesn't matter.
Use an equality test with the target which covers size and containsAll.

Please use "actual" and "expected" to be consistent with the rest of the class.
Same comment for the rest of this class.

It seems like "target" is the equivalent of "expected" in this class (see example method: RichIterable_select_reject). But the usage in here makes me believe that "target" is "actual".
In short,  you would want this to be "result" and not "target" to be consistent with the rest of the class.
"result" -> "actual"
"target" -> "expected"
e.g. assertEquals( expected, actual)
same comment as above and in the rest of this class.

commit.message:
Added flatCollect support primitive collections #794

Signed-off-by: Alxander Goldberg <alexander.goldberg@bnymellon.com>
